bunpro.meaning: There is no need to, It is fine if you don’t, Unnecessary
bunpro.meaning_warning: Noun+には及ばない is used in the comparison, to express that the Noun is no match for something it is compared with
bunpro.writeup: には及ばないis a polite expression in Japanese used in order to indicate that there is 'no need to (A)', or that '(A) is unnecessary. It is a combination of the case-marking marking particle に, theadverbial particleは, and the negated form of the う-Verb及ぶ 'to reach',及ばない. The literal translation is 'it does not extend to (A)'.This phrase will appear after nouns, or verbs in theirdictionary form.As this grammar pattern is used inpolite speech, the word that it is attached to is often preceded by either お or ご, depending on what type of verb it is.CautionWhen not used as a polite expression,には及ばないmay simply show the extent of something. This is usually when a comparison is being made between two things. This use will be translated as '(A) does not reach the extent of (B)', or '(A) cannot be compared to (B)'.

examples.japanese: こちらから前いただいたアドレスに送るので、こんな遠くまで取りに来ていただくには及びません。
examples.english: I am going to send it to the email address you gave us last time, so there is no need to come this far to pick it up.

examples.japanese: 私たちの方からそちらに書類を持っていくので、こちらまでお越しいただくには及びません。
examples.english: We will bring the documents to you, so there is no need to come here.

examples.japanese: 心配には及びません。これぐらいの怪我なら全然我慢できます。
examples.english: There is no need to worry. This level of injury is totally bearable.

examples.japanese: ここに書いてあることは皆さんもう知っていられると思うんで、説明には及びませんね。
examples.english: I think everyone already knows the contents of this, so there is no need for me to explain.

examples.japanese: あの有名ラーメン店には及ばないけど、ここのラーメンも結構美味しいと思う。
examples.english: I think the ramen here is also quite good, though not as good as that famous ramen restaurant.

examples.japanese: お宅の息子さんには及ばないかもだけど、私の息子も結構上達してきたと思う。
examples.english: Maybe not as good as your son, but I think my son has also improved a lot.

examples.japanese: 申請者「明日、書類を持って行っても差し支えありませんか?」公務員「持って来ていただくには及びません。メールでも大丈夫です。」
examples.english: Applicant: 'Would it be a problem if I bring the documents tomorrow?'Public servant: 'There is no need to bring them. It is ok if you send them via email.'

examples.japanese: 普通の人：「ありがとうございました。」偉い人：「いや、礼には及びません。」
examples.english: Ordinary person: 'Thank you very much.'Person in high position: 'No need to thank me.'

examples.japanese: 小説：バトラー「気に入ったなら、何か食べるものでもお支度致しましょうか。」ゲスト「いいえ、それには及びません。」
examples.english: A novel, butler: 'If you would like I can make something to eat.'Guest: 'No, there is no need for that.'

examples.japanese: 社員「部長、車で本社までお送りします。空港でお待ち下さい。」部長「わざわざ車で迎えに来るには及びません。近いので私がそこへ歩いていきます。」
examples.english: Company employee: 'Director, I will drive you to the headquarters. Please, wait at the airport.'Head of the department: 'No need to pick me up by car. It is close, so I will walk there myself.'

examples.japanese: はいだ「れつこさんの顔色が悪いね。」れつこ「ご心配には及びません。ただちょっと活気のないです。」
examples.english: Haida: 'Retsuko, you are pale.'Retsuko: 'No need to worry. I am just a bit tired.'
